perturbation.original_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System ("Confidential Information") is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member's attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.changed_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System ("Confidential Information") is deemed confidential, and no exceptions apply.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the exceptions, the definition of 'Confidential Information' is broadened beyond what is legally enforceable, potentially including information already in the public domain, contradicting established trade secret laws.
perturbation.law_explanation: The UTSA defines a trade secret as information that derives independent economic value from not being generally known or readily ascertainable. By stating that *all* information is confidential, regardless of whether it's publicly known, the contract attempts to protect information that doesn't meet the legal definition of a trade secret, conflicting with the UTSA.

perturbation.original_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
perturbation.changed_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the geographic restriction, the non-compete clause becomes overly broad and likely unenforceable under many state laws which require reasonable geographic limitations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
perturbation.law_citation: CA Bus. & Prof. Code ยง 16600
perturbation.law_explanation: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 generally prohibits non-compete agreements. While there are limited exceptions, such as for the sale of a business, a complete ban on competition without any geographic limitation is likely unenforceable under this statute. The original clause with the 3-mile radius provides some specificity and potential enforceability that is lost with this change.

perturbation.original_text: Member acknowledges that any failure to comply with the requirements of this Agreement will cause Franchisor irreparable injury, and Member agrees to pay all court costs and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by Franchisor in obtaining specific performance of, or an injunction against violation of, the requirements of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Member acknowledges that any failure to comply with the requirements of this Agreement will cause Franchisor injury, and Member agrees to pay all attorney's fees incurred by Franchisor in obtaining specific performance of, or an injunction against violation of, the requirements of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "irreparable" and "reasonable," it makes it seem like the injury does not have to be proven for the Franchisor to win the case. Also, removing "reasonable" before "attorney fees" makes it seem like they could attempt to get the Member to pay excessive attorney fees.
perturbation.law_explanation: This section speaks about unconscionability. A contract can be deemed unconscionable if the terms are so unfair to one party that no reasonable person in the position of the weaker party would have agreed to them, and the contract is one that no fair and honest person would have bothered accepting. Removing 'irreparable injury' and 'reasonable' attorney's fees could lead to an unconscionable penalty and may make this agreement unenforceable.
